Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Turbulent Flame Structure of Cavity Stabilized Reacting Shear Layers: Effects of Flow Compressibility, Heat Release, and Finite-rate Kinetics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511791(Chelliah)/1511520(Cutler)/1510222(Edwards)

High-speed and supersonic combustion is of vital importance to high-speed transport. The research team comprised of experimentalist and numerical modelers will try to understand, using a unique facility and state-of-art numerical models, how fuel burning at such high speed happens and how stable combustion can be achieved. A team of undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in the research and the data and results will be widely published.

To understand the flame stabilization mechanism requires the understanding flame structure resulting from the interaction between the chemical reaction, which releases heat, and the flow. Under high-speed conditions, the flow is turbulent. The proposal focuses on this interaction under supersonic conditions where compressibility also plays a role. The flow geometry chosen is high-speed reacting shear flow over cavity, which is commonly believed to be a good candidate for supersonic combustion and propulsion. The proposed facility (located at the lead PI's institution - UVa) is unique, which has been developed over the past decades and is well and appropriately leveraged for the proposed research. Fundamental data on flame structure and statistics on key species are to be obtained experimentally. Computational results using DNS (Direct Numerical Simulation) will supplement the experiments to provide additional information not accessible from experiments in developing submodels, which can be used in the future development of high-speed propulsion combustors. The experimental data are of archival value. Close collaboration proposed with researchers from government labs would likely amplify its usefulness.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this multi-institutional investigation with joint funding from NSF-AFOSR, the fundamental mechanism of anchoring turbulent flames in high-speed, compressible flows was investigated using variety of experimental and computational tools. The team included faculty and students, both graduate and undergraduate, from the University of Virginia, North Carolina State University, and George Washing University. Scientists from the Sandia National Laboratory at Livermore, CA, and from NASA Langley Research Center at Hampton, VA, were also involved in advising and hosting students at respective laboratories. The knowledge gained form the work performed can be used in design and optimization of a new generation of highly efficient, propulsion systems with intense coupling between turbulent and chemical energy modes. Typical targeted applications include large civil aviation jet engines and hypersonic propulsion systems for national defense.    

 

The research conducted addressed two fundamental research issues, (i) fuel-air mixing in high-speed turbulent flows and (ii) chemical reaction and heat release of partially stratified premixed flows in the presence of turbulent mixing. In this work, the fuel was introduced from one wall (of a duct) into a Mach 2 air stream and allowed to mix. The mixing process was analyzed by numerical method using a hybrid Large Eddy Simulations (LES) and Reynolds Averaged Navier Stokes (RANS) models and by experiments using Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Spectroscopy (CARS) diagnostics, and have shown that, after going through a series of sock trains, the fuel-air mixture achieved near complete mixing with some stratifications near the center. When the flame was stabilized over a novel additively manufactured and scaled down cavity flame holder, the anchored flame structure resembled the features very similar to those of wall mounted large cavity flame holders. Furthermore, scaled down version allowed highest numerical resolution of the flame structure in these high-speed flows via Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) methods with newly implemented higher-order Immerse Boundary Methods. These results have revealed flame structures of the order of one hundred micro meters and approaching about five times that of smallest dissipative length scales (Kolmogorov length scales). Furthermore, high resolution Planar Laser Induced Fluorescence (PLIF) of hydroxyl (OH) radicals allowed experimental confirmation of predicted highly turbulent flame structures via DNS and hybrid LES-RANS methods. Measurement flow velocities via particle image velocimetric (PIV) techniques was crucial in defining the inflow boundary to the DNS computational domain. The extensive amount of data gathered, both experimental and computational, have been shared with various groups to advance the novel computational methods and optimization of compressible, turbulent reacting flows.  

 

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2021
Modified by: Christopher P Goyne

The team included faculty and students, both graduate and undergraduate, from the University of Virginia, North Carolina State University, and George Washing University. Scientists from the Sandia National Laboratory at Livermore, CA, and from NASA Langley Research Center at Hampton, VA, were also involved in advising and hosting students at respective laboratories. The knowledge gained form the work performed can be used in design and optimization of a new generation of highly efficient, propulsion systems with intense coupling between turbulent and chemical energy modes. Typical targeted applications include large civil aviation jet engines and hypersonic propulsion systems for national defense. The research conducted addressed two fundamental research issues, (i) fuel-air mixing in high-speed turbulent flows and (ii) chemical reaction and heat release of partially stratified premixed flows in the presence of turbulent mixing. In this work, the fuel was introduced from one wall (of a duct) into a Mach 2 air stream and allowed to mix.
